DECORATIONS

DRAPERIES

ENGINEERS ELECT CHAIRMEN
Three Branches of the Engineering Society Decide to Consolidate—Stuart,
Howard and Young, All of '17
Class, Chosen as Leaders.

Another step toward a closer
organization of the Johns Hopkins Engineering Society was
taken at a meeting of the society
last Monday, in the lecture-hall of
the Mechanical and Electrical
Building, when chairmen of the
three branches—civil, mechanical
and electrical—were chosen.
At a recent meeting of the members of the society it was decided
that the three divisions compose
the society, thus centralizing the
interest, rather than having three
separate societies, each specializing in its own,branch of study.
The plan adopted is that there
shall be meetings at certain intervals, and that the various
branches shall alternate in having
charge of the meetings. Thus the
members of one division of engineering will have the opportimity
of hearing a report or talk on interesting and practical problems
which confront the men in other
phases of the engineering work.
The men nominated by their respective branches were: J. Trueman Thompson and Edward M.
Stuart, of the mechanical engineering department; Stanley E.
Howard, of the civil department;
and Louis McC. Young and Everett E. Perkins, of the electrical department. The election of the
chairmen was taken up by the entire society, which chose E. M.
Stuart, S. E. Howard and L. McC.
Young, all of the 1917 class.
Interest in the Engineering Society is growing considerably, and
it promises soon to become one of
the most important of the student
activities. At other colleges offices on the Engineering Society
hoard are looked upon as coveted
honors. At the University of
Wisconsin, for instance, where
both Prof. C. C. Thomas and Prof.
A. G. Christie, instructors in mechanical engineering here, taught
for several years, the election of
the gociety was one of the big
events of the year.
Interesting talks will be arranged by the society, and the student-body as a whole are invited
to attend. Most of the lectures
will be illustrated with slides.

1110 (1011ii3 [101)113NOt-I0110C

him a higher social status, he is
riding for a fall. Some college
men, too—not the average ones,
fortunately—have a pride in their
mental attainments that is almost
• arrogance. Employers find it difficult to control, guide and train
such men. Their spirit of superiority bars the path of progress.
"Most college meu are free from
this false pride. But occasionally
employers come in contact with
one who has it, and judge all college men by him. In business we
buy by sample, and sometimes the
wrong sort of sample from an institution of higher lethming makes
an employer feel as Robert Hall
felt when he wrote of Kippis that
'He might be a very clever man by
nature, for aught I know, but he
laid so many books on top of his
head that his brains could not
move.'
"For some college men it is a
hard descent from the heights of
theory to the plains of everyday
facts and common sense. Sometimes years of book learning come
to grief before a problem that is
disposed of out of hand by men
whose wits have been ground to
an edge by practical everyday experience.
"Thomas A. Edison who never
saw the inside of a college as a
student, once had in his laboratory a man fresh from one of our
great universities, where he had
been graduated at the head of his
class. Soon this young Bachelor
of Arts met much that upset his
pet theories. But he would not readjust these theories. When
things were done contrary to rules
laid down in the books, he looked
on with indulgence.
"One day Mr. Edison unscrewed
from its socket an incandescent
-electric light bulb.'Find the cubic
contents of this!' he said to the
college graduate.
"To work out the problem by
mathematical rote was about as
difficult as squaring the circle.
But the college student went at it
boldly. Reams of paper were figured and disfigured by his energetic pencil during the next few
days. Finally he brought to Mr.
Edison the result of his calculations. 'You're at least 10 per cent.
out of the way,' said the inventor.
The graduate, sublimely confident, disputed this.
"All right,' said Edison calmly. 'Let's find out.'
"The graduate took out his pencil, ready for another siege at mathematics; but the inventor quietly picked up a small hammer and
knocked the tip off the blown end
of the bulb. Then he filled the
bulb with water, weighed it.
and in about a minute had arrived
absolutely at the result. It showed
that the complex mathematical
calculations of the college man
were at least 10 per cent, out of
the may.
"Fortunately, the lesson went
home, and afterward the star student became an excellent practical electrician."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER
13, 1916.

HOPKINS MAN WINS THIRD PLACE
Weeks Makes Fine Showing in South
Atlantic Six-Mile Cross-Country
Run at the Catholic
University.

HOPKINS AT HOMEWOOD

May thou, who hast unto a grateful world
Made known Johns Hopkins' name forever more,
And set thy standard so sublimely high
That "Veritas Vos Liberabit" stands
The crystallized expression of thyself;
Guard now this noble heritage of thine,
Remote from all transgressions of today.
God grant thou, University that bore
Haupt, Rowland, Remsen, Gilman, Gildersleeve,
And all the heroes of thy splendid past,
Be not immured with red brick and white wood,
Forgetting, in thy heritage, the minds
Who, by their toil, have made it justly thine
But let the beacon thou hast set on high
Shine out, serene, above its splendid home;
Nor e'er grow dim that brick and stone may rise.
1917.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 13, 1916.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

All letters intended for publication must
be concise.
No attention will be paid to anonymous
letters, but names signed as an evidence of
good faith will not be printed if request is
made that they be omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to be
taken as an indorsement of its views by THE
NEWS-I,Errim, which invites the freest discussion of matters of general interest.

An Answer.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Sir—In answer to the letters of
the "Would-Be Rooter," a few remarks seem to be in order. However, before speaking of his
article, it seems proper to question the sincerity of a reformer,
who does not have backbone
enough to shoulder the responsibility of his ideas by signing his
name to his letter. A man who
wishes to accomplish a reformation must not start out by making
the mistake of doing the thing he
wishes to have reformed. He
should not show mere half-hearted
interest and lack of real spirit,
but, if he has any faith in his
ideas and convictions, he sholild
be both willing to acknowledge
and to fight for them.
The attitude of the "Would-Be
Rooter," and others of the student-body who agree with him,
namely, the lack of true interest,
earnest desire, stability of purpose, and ,loyal support, along
with the unwillingness to bear
full responsibility, to fight and
undergo a defeat seems to me to
be the trouble with Hopkins. If
the football team is winning,
everything is all right; but as
soon as the team takes a slump—
loses a game—then the talk begins. The team coaches and management come in for their share
of criticism, which, in most cases,
they are far from meriting. Failing to see that under these circumstances, when things look
blue, the team needs help and encouragement, is what needs correction. Therefore, if you desire
a change in the athletic policy,
wait until the time of policymaking and urge it; if the students want it they will adopt it
at the proper time, but do not
you, as one of them, sieze the moment when those, whom you have
chosen to carry out the accepted
policies, are in the press of doubtful battle to ridicule the plan and
assail the leaders from cover of
such a pseudonym as "Would-Be
Rooter." Every Hopkins man is a
"Should-Be Rooter."
The writer said in his fist letter,
"the fault does not lie with us,
it lies with the Athletic Association." What is the Athletic Association but another .form of the
student body who compose and
control it? The management of
the Athletic Association can merely carry out the policies of its
members, and it has done this in

the most.efficient and satisfactory
manner which was possible with
the means in its hand. It was
said that its policy was primarily
to make money, and then the use
of old football equipment was
quoted to uphold this point. , In
answer I would like to state that
it is not a question of making,
but of not going in a debt which
keeps the management from
making expenditures. How much
easier it would be if the managers
could simply buy and not worry
over how these bills are paid. I
am sure that the management
would be delighted to purchase
equipment if some one else were
paying the bills, or if they knew
from what source funds to meet
these expenditures were to be
drawn.
To discuss the question of football equipment in particular, I
would like to state that a sum of
money which would have more
than thoroughly equipped a former
Hopkins team has been spent, but
that this year, with 56 candidates
out for the team, the, strain on
the management to furnish equipment has been very great. This
necessarily requires the use of
some old equipment, and as is
the custom at other large colleges,
this equipment is given to the second-string men, while the 'varsity
receives the new outfits.
The managerial system, which
the writer called a farce, is the
most effective system at the present time in use at any of the other
universities or colleges. That this
system in itself is excellent seems
unnecessary to prove, for it is selfevident. The working of such a
system is always limited by the
material it has to work with, and,
if the system fails to turn out efficient managers, it is because the
student body has not taken
enough interest individually and
as a whole to insure its best results. Only by having keen competition among the assistant managers, and a general interest in
the selection of the manager by
the board, can good managers be
obtained.
However, the question is again
reduced to the fact that the student body controls the Athletic
Association and, if it does not
like the managerial system, or the
workings of such a system, it is
up to it to change them. Failing to do this, the student body
should endeavor to support the
system in its workings. In other
words—do something. Change it,
or support it, but don't just talk.
The statement that Charlie
Brickley was brought to Hopkins
simply as a financial policy is absurd. The alumni and football
advisors thought that they might
arouse the undergraduates by
bringing to Hopkins a coach who
had just finished his college career, and who could turn out a
successful team. They secured
Brickley; their hopes and ours
were realized. We turned out a
team Hopkins can be proud of.

This year, under the guidance of
Coach Brennick, •we start well,
then a defeat, and the student
body begins to talk. One little
defeat, and they start to knock,
instead of supporting the team,
coaches and management.
The remedy suggested by the
writer in his letter seems worthy
of consideration, and I am sure if
presented to the Athletic Board
they would be glad to bring this
plan before the student body.
However, we smust bear this in
mind, that simply making rules,
either excluding graduate students, or limiting a man to four
years of football, will not give us
a team. Neither will the hiring
of expert coaches accomplish this
result alone. What the remedy
requires for its success is an
awakening of the student body.
Not only an awakening, but also
a spirit of fight, to stick, and to
risk defeat, if necessary.
In conclusion, then, it is up to
the students to change what they

do not like, but before making
these changes let them be sure
that they are willing to work and
fight to make their venture a success, and to accept defeat with
its hardships, if fate so ordains.
If they are willing to venture,
even if they lose, they shall have
gained.
If, on the other hand, we accept the present policies, let us,
not hinder or censure the management who are working to carry
out these policies in the most effective manner; rather, let us
lend our heartiest support.
WILLIAM KENDALL, JR.
November 10, 1916.

Immediately at the close of the

team. It was a spontaneous celebration resulting from the fact
that the slogan, "Beat Western
Maryland" had indeed become a
reality.
Hopkins scored her first touchdown in record time. An exchange
of punts shortly after the game
had started gave the pigskin to
Hopkins on the 30-yard line. The
Black and Blue eleven settled
down in earnest for a touchdown,
and with the Hopkins line opening up the holes, Tillett, Brooks,
Hopkins and Branham took turns
in advancing the ball until Brooks
went across for the first touchdown. Branham kicked goal.
It looked like an easy victory for
Hopkins, but Western Maryland
rallied and from that time until shortly after the opening of
the last quarter, the spectators
were given a chance to witness as
pretty a football duel as seen in
these parts for some time. Western Maryland tried hard to break
down the sturdy Hopkins defense,
but found it impossible. Even the
heralded Garrett could not penetrate the solid wall of defense, except for small gains. The Methodists tried forward passes galore,
wide end runs and plenty of
straight line plunges, but were unable to score on the Black and
Blue. They nearly scored in the
second quarter when Western
Maryland had a first down on
Hopkins' six-yard line. But the
Black and Blue line was equal to
the occasion and for four downs

wall, taking the ball away from

DECORATIONS

DRAPERIES

ENGINEERS ELECT CHAIRMEN
Three Branches of the Engineering Society Decide to Consolidate—Stuart,
Howard and Young, All of '17
Class, Chosen as Leaders.

Another step toward a closer
organization of the Johns Hopkins Engineering Society was
taken at a meeting of the society
last Monday, in the lecture-hall of
the Mechanical and Electrical
Building, when chairmen of the
three branches—civil, mechanical
and electrical—were chosen.
At a recent meeting of the members of the society it was decided
that the three divisions compose
the society, thus centralizing the
interest, rather than having three
separate societies, each specializing in its own,branch of study.
The plan adopted is that there
shall be meetings at certain intervals, and that the various
branches shall alternate in having
charge of the meetings. Thus the
members of one division of engineering will have the opportimity
of hearing a report or talk on interesting and practical problems
which confront the men in other
phases of the engineering work.
The men nominated by their respective branches were: J. Trueman Thompson and Edward M.
Stuart, of the mechanical engineering department; Stanley E.
Howard, of the civil department;
and Louis McC. Young and Everett E. Perkins, of the electrical department. The election of the
chairmen was taken up by the entire society, which chose E. M.
Stuart, S. E. Howard and L. McC.
Young, all of the 1917 class.
Interest in the Engineering Society is growing considerably, and
it promises soon to become one of
the most important of the student
activities. At other colleges offices on the Engineering Society
hoard are looked upon as coveted
honors. At the University of
Wisconsin, for instance, where
both Prof. C. C. Thomas and Prof.
A. G. Christie, instructors in mechanical engineering here, taught
for several years, the election of
the gociety was one of the big
events of the year.
Interesting talks will be arranged by the society, and the student-body as a whole are invited
to attend. Most of the lectures
will be illustrated with slides.

man thinks that his education gives

1110 (1011ii3 [101)113NOt-I0110C

him a higher social status, he is
riding for a fall. Some college
men, too—not the average ones,
fortunately—have a pride in their
mental attainments that is almost
• arrogance. Employers find it difficult to control, guide and train
such men. Their spirit of superiority bars the path of progress.
"Most college meu are free from
this false pride. But occasionally
employers come in contact with
one who has it, and judge all college men by him. In business we
buy by sample, and sometimes the
wrong sort of sample from an institution of higher lethming makes
an employer feel as Robert Hall
felt when he wrote of Kippis that
'He might be a very clever man by
nature, for aught I know, but he
laid so many books on top of his
head that his brains could not
move.'
"For some college men it is a
hard descent from the heights of
theory to the plains of everyday
facts and common sense. Sometimes years of book learning come
to grief before a problem that is
disposed of out of hand by men
whose wits have been ground to
an edge by practical everyday experience.
"Thomas A. Edison who never
saw the inside of a college as a
student, once had in his laboratory a man fresh from one of our
great universities, where he had
been graduated at the head of his
class. Soon this young Bachelor
of Arts met much that upset his
pet theories. But he would not readjust these theories. When
things were done contrary to rules
laid down in the books, he looked
on with indulgence.
"One day Mr. Edison unscrewed
from its socket an incandescent
-electric light bulb.'Find the cubic
contents of this!' he said to the
college graduate.
"To work out the problem by
mathematical rote was about as
difficult as squaring the circle.
But the college student went at it
boldly. Reams of paper were figured and disfigured by his energetic pencil during the next few
days. Finally he brought to Mr.
Edison the result of his calculations. 'You're at least 10 per cent.
out of the way,' said the inventor.
The graduate, sublimely confident, disputed this.
"All right,' said Edison calmly. 'Let's find out.'
"The graduate took out his pencil, ready for another siege at mathematics; but the inventor quietly picked up a small hammer and
knocked the tip off the blown end
of the bulb. Then he filled the
bulb with water, weighed it.
and in about a minute had arrived
absolutely at the result. It showed
that the complex mathematical
calculations of the college man
were at least 10 per cent, out of
the may.
"Fortunately, the lesson went
home, and afterward the star student became an excellent practical electrician."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER
13, 1916.

HOPKINS MAN WINS THIRD PLACE
Weeks Makes Fine Showing in South
Atlantic Six-Mile Cross-Country
Run at the Catholic
University.

HOPKINS AT HOMEWOOD

May thou, who hast unto a grateful world
Made known Johns Hopkins' name forever more,
And set thy standard so sublimely high
That "Veritas Vos Liberabit" stands
The crystallized expression of thyself;
Guard now this noble heritage of thine,
Remote from all transgressions of today.
God grant thou, University that bore
Haupt, Rowland, Remsen, Gilman, Gildersleeve,
And all the heroes of thy splendid past,
Be not immured with red brick and white wood,
Forgetting, in thy heritage, the minds
Who, by their toil, have made it justly thine
But let the beacon thou hast set on high
Shine out, serene, above its splendid home;
Nor e'er grow dim that brick and stone may rise.
1917.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 13, 1916.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

All letters intended for publication must
be concise.
No attention will be paid to anonymous
letters, but names signed as an evidence of
good faith will not be printed if request is
made that they be omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to be
taken as an indorsement of its views by THE
NEWS-I,Errim, which invites the freest discussion of matters of general interest.

An Answer.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Sir—In answer to the letters of
the "Would-Be Rooter," a few remarks seem to be in order. However, before speaking of his
article, it seems proper to question the sincerity of a reformer,
who does not have backbone
enough to shoulder the responsibility of his ideas by signing his
name to his letter. A man who
wishes to accomplish a reformation must not start out by making
the mistake of doing the thing he
wishes to have reformed. He
should not show mere half-hearted
interest and lack of real spirit,
but, if he has any faith in his
ideas and convictions, he sholild
be both willing to acknowledge
and to fight for them.
The attitude of the "Would-Be
Rooter," and others of the student-body who agree with him,
namely, the lack of true interest,
earnest desire, stability of purpose, and ,loyal support, along
with the unwillingness to bear
full responsibility, to fight and
undergo a defeat seems to me to
be the trouble with Hopkins. If
the football team is winning,
everything is all right; but as
soon as the team takes a slump—
loses a game—then the talk begins. The team coaches and management come in for their share
of criticism, which, in most cases,
they are far from meriting. Failing to see that under these circumstances, when things look
blue, the team needs help and encouragement, is what needs correction. Therefore, if you desire
a change in the athletic policy,
wait until the time of policymaking and urge it; if the students want it they will adopt it
at the proper time, but do not
you, as one of them, sieze the moment when those, whom you have
chosen to carry out the accepted
policies, are in the press of doubtful battle to ridicule the plan and
assail the leaders from cover of
such a pseudonym as "Would-Be
Rooter." Every Hopkins man is a
"Should-Be Rooter."
The writer said in his fist letter,
"the fault does not lie with us,
it lies with the Athletic Association." What is the Athletic Association but another .form of the
student body who compose and
control it? The management of
the Athletic Association can merely carry out the policies of its
members, and it has done this in

the most.efficient and satisfactory
manner which was possible with
the means in its hand. It was
said that its policy was primarily
to make money, and then the use
of old football equipment was
quoted to uphold this point. , In
answer I would like to state that
it is not a question of making,
but of not going in a debt which
keeps the management from
making expenditures. How much
easier it would be if the managers
could simply buy and not worry
over how these bills are paid. I
am sure that the management
would be delighted to purchase
equipment if some one else were
paying the bills, or if they knew
from what source funds to meet
these expenditures were to be
drawn.
To discuss the question of football equipment in particular, I
would like to state that a sum of
money which would have more
than thoroughly equipped a former
Hopkins team has been spent, but
that this year, with 56 candidates
out for the team, the, strain on
the management to furnish equipment has been very great. This
necessarily requires the use of
some old equipment, and as is
the custom at other large colleges,
this equipment is given to the second-string men, while the 'varsity
receives the new outfits.
The managerial system, which
the writer called a farce, is the
most effective system at the present time in use at any of the other
universities or colleges. That this
system in itself is excellent seems
unnecessary to prove, for it is selfevident. The working of such a
system is always limited by the
material it has to work with, and,
if the system fails to turn out efficient managers, it is because the
student body has not taken
enough interest individually and
as a whole to insure its best results. Only by having keen competition among the assistant managers, and a general interest in
the selection of the manager by
the board, can good managers be
obtained.
However, the question is again
reduced to the fact that the student body controls the Athletic
Association and, if it does not
like the managerial system, or the
workings of such a system, it is
up to it to change them. Failing to do this, the student body
should endeavor to support the
system in its workings. In other
words—do something. Change it,
or support it, but don't just talk.
The statement that Charlie
Brickley was brought to Hopkins
simply as a financial policy is absurd. The alumni and football
advisors thought that they might
arouse the undergraduates by
bringing to Hopkins a coach who
had just finished his college career, and who could turn out a
successful team. They secured
Brickley; their hopes and ours
were realized. We turned out a
team Hopkins can be proud of.

This year, under the guidance of
Coach Brennick, •we start well,
then a defeat, and the student
body begins to talk. One little
defeat, and they start to knock,
instead of supporting the team,
coaches and management.
The remedy suggested by the
writer in his letter seems worthy
of consideration, and I am sure if
presented to the Athletic Board
they would be glad to bring this
plan before the student body.
However, we smust bear this in
mind, that simply making rules,
either excluding graduate students, or limiting a man to four
years of football, will not give us
a team. Neither will the hiring
of expert coaches accomplish this
result alone. What the remedy
requires for its success is an
awakening of the student body.
Not only an awakening, but also
a spirit of fight, to stick, and to
risk defeat, if necessary.
In conclusion, then, it is up to
the students to change what they

do not like, but before making
these changes let them be sure
that they are willing to work and
fight to make their venture a success, and to accept defeat with
its hardships, if fate so ordains.
If they are willing to venture,
even if they lose, they shall have
gained.
If, on the other hand, we accept the present policies, let us,
not hinder or censure the management who are working to carry
out these policies in the most effective manner; rather, let us
lend our heartiest support.
WILLIAM KENDALL, JR.
November 10, 1916.

the opening of the first quarter.
But Western Maryland rallied
and for nearly three quarters the
ball went back and forth with
neither team able to score. However, Western Maryland could
not stand the pace and when in
the last quarter the defense of the
Methodists seemed to crumble,
Hopkins scored two additional
touchdowns.
Immediately at the close of the
contest, the Hopkins student-body
swarmed on the field and repeated
the performance of the week previous after the Swarthmore game,
but with a much larger proportion of the student-body participating. The victorious players
were carried off the gridiron and
then a snakedance was given with
at least 300 students in line:After
a huge "H" had been formed in
the center of the field the students retired to outside the lockerroom to cheer the members of the
team. It was a spontaneous celebration resulting from the fact
that the slogan, "Beat Western
Maryland" had indeed become a
reality.
Hopkins scored her first touchdown in record time. An exchange
of punts shortly after the game
had started gave the pigskin to
Hopkins on the 30-yard line. The
Black and Blue eleven settled
down in earnest for a touchdown,
and with the Hopkins line opening up the holes, Tillett, Brooks,
Hopkins and Branham took turns
in advancing the ball until Brooks
went across for the first touchdown. Branham kicked goal.
It looked like an easy victory for
Hopkins, but Western Maryland
rallied and from that time until shortly after the opening of
the last quarter, the spectators
were given a chance to witness as
pretty a football duel as seen in
these parts for some time. Western Maryland tried hard to break
down the sturdy Hopkins defense,
but found it impossible. Even the
heralded Garrett could not penetrate the solid wall of defense, except for small gains. The Methodists tried forward passes galore,
wide end runs and plenty of
straight line plunges, but were unable to score on the Black and
Blue. They nearly scored in the
second quarter when Western
Maryland had a first down on
Hopkins' six-yard line. But the
Black and Blue line was equal to
the occasion and for four downs
the local line held like a stone
wall, taking the ball away from
the visitors.

touchdown a few minutes after
